I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During a series of dialogues between the Government of Cambodia and the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  on  ADB's  country  program  for  Cambodia,  the  Government 
emphasized the need for a renewed strategy for national agricultural research and consensus 
building  among  key  stakeholders  for  the  strategy.  In April 2003, the Government officially 
requested ADB for technical assistance (TA) to prepare a master plan for national agricultural 
research.  ADB  fielded  the  TA  Fact-finding  Mission  in  October  2003,  which  reached  an 
understanding with the Government on the objective, scope, implementation arrangements, and 
terms of reference for the TA. The TA is included in the ADB’s 2003 TA program for Cambodia 
under the country strategy and program update (2004–2006).1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  In Cambodia, the agriculture sector remains a major contributor to the national economy, 
accounting for 39% of the gross domestic product and employing about 70% of the total 
workforce. Sustainable agricultural growth is essential for the broad-based improvement of 
people's livelihoods in the country. Rice self-sufficiency was achieved in Cambodia over the 
past decade as a result of improved varieties and cropping systems. However, yield levels and 
cropping intensities remain low compared with those in similar ecosystems in the neighboring 
countries. Most farmers comprise smallholders with less than 1 hectare per household and 
using subsistence farming systems. An important constraint on agricultural commercialization 
and diversification for increased cash income is the limited access of farmers to improved 
technology and knowledge due primarily to insufficient investments in agricultural research and 
extension. As a result, farmers' linkages with urban and international markets and agribusiness 
are extremely weak. 
 
3.  In  1998,  the  Government  approved  a  national  policy  for  agricultural  research  and 
extension to establish a sustainable system in the long run.2 This policy called for (i) the 
establishment of a semi-autonomous core research institute; (ii) stakeholder participation in the 
organization, management, and implementation of research and extension; (iii) client focus of 
agricultural research and extension services; (iv) promotion of private sector participation in the 
delivery of research and extension services where possible; (v) well-defined responsibilities of 
government agencies in service delivery; and (vi) human resource development for improved 
quality of services. While part of the policy has been implemented, including the establishment 
of  the  Cambodian  Agricultural  Research  and  Development  Institute  (CARDI)  as  a  primary 
institution for national rice research, the approved policy has not been widely known or adopted 
to guide public investments in agricultural research and extension due to the lack of follow-up 
activities  to  disseminate  and  implement  the  policy.  As  a  result,  essential  dialogue  and 
awareness-building activities on research and extension have been limited. 
 
4.  Under  the  Second  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (SEDPII:  2001–2005),  the 
Government aims at transforming agriculture into a driving force for sustainable economic 
growth, poverty reduction, and employment generation. SEDPII's agriculture strategy is to 
promote commercialization and agro-industry development in the policy framework for a liberal 
and market-oriented trade environment. One of the important strategic thrusts of SEDPII is to 
use essential agricultural research and extension services to improve the knowledge and skills

of farmers for different agro-ecological zones and farming systems. In Cambodia, the national 
capacity for agricultural research in terms of management, organization, facilities, and human 
resources needs to be substantially strengthened. Although some capacity for rice research 
exists  at  CARDI  with  the  long-term  support  from  the  Government  of  Australia  and  the 
International Rice Research Institute, the knowledge base is particularly weak for production of 
crops  other  than  rice,  and  for  fishery,  livestock,  and  forestry  subsectors.  Consequently, 
technology and information are insufficiently tested for transfer to farmers by the agricultural 
extension  system,  farmers  have  a  limited  ability  for  agricultural  diversification  and 
commercialization,  and  Cambodia  has  poor  capability  to  identify  and  adapt  promising 
technology from neighboring countries.  
 
5.  Agricultural commercialization depends on improvements in product quality together with 
appropriately developed value chains, policies, and regulations. Institutional capacity for the 
development,  testing,  and  dissemination  of  improved  technology  and  information  is  also 
fundamental to agricultural transformation, with the capacity of national agricultural research the 
key to scientific advances in agriculture. 
 
6.  Because Cambodia has complex agricultural research requirements, the Government 
recognizes the need for better management of national agricultural research. Multiple partners 
are involved in agricultural research and extension in Cambodia, including departments and 
institutes in different government ministries, universities, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), 
private  business,  and  external  funding  agencies.  To  achieve  advances  in  the  growth  of 
sustainable agriculture, these partners need to become a functioning national system with 
shared  perceptions,  vision,  and  objectives  for  technology-led improvements in agricultural 
productivity  and  product  quality.  The  currently  overlapping  research  activities  need  to  be 
streamlined to use scarce national resources effectively. A master plan for national agricultural 
research offers opportunities for public and private stakeholders to examine the current situation 
of research, resolve strategic and organizational issues, and develop shared research programs 
and priorities. 
 
7.  At present, major constraints to enhancing a national agricultural research system exist 
in the following areas: 
(i)  Financial  resources.  An  effective  system  is  required  to  plan  and  manage 
medium-term fiscal resources for agriculture so that scarce resources can be 
properly allocated for priority research programs in a well structured manner. The 
Government has decided to introduce a medium-term expenditure framework 
into  agriculture  from  2004,  to  strengthen  the  planning  and  management  of 
resources in the sector. ADB’s Agriculture Sector Development Program3 will 
complement  the  TA  and  accelerate  introduction  of  a  proper  medium-term 
framework. 
(ii)  Human resources.  Planning and management of scientific and management 
staff  for  research  appear  substantially  weak  with  no  formal  or  objective 
procedures  for  recruitment,  performance  assessment,  advancement,  or 
sanctions.  Recommendations  for  the  design  of  such  a  system  need  to  be 
developed and adopted. Appropriate criteria and guidelines for human resource 
planning and management with an adequate incentive system are needed for

acquiring  scientific  technical  skills  and  training  required,  based  on  research 
program planning and priority setting. 
(iii)  Information  management.  Information  management  systems  that  link 
information on research activities, funds, personnel, and facilities at different 
levels of the system are required for developing a national research system. The 
lack  of  such  systems  often  leads  to  poor  management  of  resources  for 
agricultural  research,  and  hampers  adjustments  in  ongoing  research  and 
determination of research results and impacts. 
(iv)  Research facilities. The facilities of universities and research institutes need to 
be  rehabilitated,  and  strengthened  to  the  required  minimum  for  supporting 
essential  research  activities  under  a  renewed  strategy.  In  this  context,  a 
comprehensive assessment is needed of the number and location of institutes, 
and the facilities and equipment, and to help establish a lean and sustainable 
national system. 
 
8.  A master plan for national agricultural research is needed to address these current 
issues and to generate the country's strong ownership for (i) establishing a renewed strategy for 
research, (ii) clarifying and agreeing on scientific objectives and priorities, (iii) planning the 
research program contents to implement those priorities, and (iv) defining the resources needed 
for carrying out these plans. The master plan will also identify means to improve the structure, 
organization and management of agricultural research, and strengthen linkages at different 
levels among research and extension services, farmers, and private businesses. It will help 
establish a national agricultural research system, capable of planning and carrying out high 
priority adaptive and applied research in collaboration with a wide range of stakeholders, 
including universities, colleges, international research organizations, NGOs, farmer groups, and 
other  private  sector  organizations  to  support  the  commercialization  and  diversification  of 
agriculture. 
 
9.  The TA is in line with ADB's sector strategy to help achieve the Government's objectives 
of  sustainable  agricultural  growth  and  reduction  in  rural  poverty.  It  will  also  contribute  to 
promoting private sector participation in agriculture, and improving farmers' access to productive 
opportunities.  The  TA  is  essential  for  formulating  the  proposed  master  plan  for  national 
agricultural research and market-oriented agricultural growth. Major external funding agencies in 
the agriculture sector fully support the process of the master plan formulation. The TA will 
complement the activities of other projects and programs of ADB and other external funding 
agencies. Based on the ADB's operations experiences, the TA will involve a wide range of 
stakeholders to reflect their views in the discussions on national agricultural research. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
10.  The TA will assist the Government in formulating a master plan for national agricultural 
research that will provide strategic direction and identify priority research objectives for the 
medium term. The initiative will strengthen national agricultural research by defining areas for 
the improvement of research policy, strategy, and management, and by identifying priority 
objectives and activities to be shared by partners in agricultural research. The logical framework 
for the TA is in Appendix 1.

4 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will be carried out in three phases: (i) review and assessment of the existing 
policies and strategies for agricultural research and extension, (ii) development of a renewed 
strategy for national agricultural research in the medium term, and (iii) identification of the 
priority research programs based on current and future research needs in the agriculture sector. 
 
12.  The TA will (i) study the current state and inventory of the national agricultural research 
system  in  terms  of  institutional  setting,  research  facilities,  research  staff  capacity,  service 
conditions, funding, priorities, organization and management of research, and linkages with 
farmers  and  other  partners;  (ii)  examine  the  research  system’s  strengths,  weaknesses, 
opportunities, and threats in relation to rapidly changing internal and external environments, 
including export markets; (iii) examine lessons from and experience of other countries in South 
and Southeast Asia in developing an effective and participatory national agricultural research 
system; (iv) recommend alternative structural options for establishing a lean and sustainable 
agricultural  research  system  to  ensure  good  governance  and  management;  (v)  promote 
research linkages and partnerships with universities, agencies involved in extension services, 
regional and international research organizations, agro-processing industries and agribusiness, 
and external funding agencies; (vi) assess environmental and gender concerns to be integrated 
in agricultural research; (vii) assess needs for research personnel; information management 
systems; and monitoring, evaluation, and impact assessments; and (viii) study possible access 
to  agricultural  biotechnology  and  its  proper  use.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  the 
consultants are in Appendix 2. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $360,000  equivalent,  comprising  $195,000  in  foreign 
exchange costs and $165,000 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will provide $300,000 to 
finance the entire foreign exchange costs and part of the local  currency costs, amounting to 
$105,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from  ADB-funded TA Special 
Fund. The balance of the local currency costs, amounting to $60,000 equivalent, will be met by 
the Government to cover office accommodations, counterpart staff support, facilities for seminars 
and meetings, and other administrative expenses and part of field transport. A Government 
representative will be invited as an observer for TA contract negotiations. The detailed cost 
estimates are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (MAFF) will be the Executing Agency 
for the TA, and have overall responsibility for TA implementation. A project coordinator for the 
TA will be appointed by MAFF. MAFF satisfactorily implemented an ADB loan for the Agriculture 
Sector Program and its related TA,4 and has adequate capacity to implement the TA. Since the 
TA will be a national planning exercise covering a wide range of subsectors and activities in the 
agriculture sector, an agricultural research steering committee will be established at MAFF to 
guide the TA activities with representatives of relevant departments of MAFF, the Council for 
Agricultural and Rural Development, other agencies of the Government, research institutes, 
universities, civil society organizations, private business, and external funding agencies. CARDI

5 
will serve as a secretariat for the steering committee. There will be working groups for the 
subsectors of crops, livestock, fishery, forestry and agro-industry, each headed by a leading 
scientist in an appropriate discipline and comprising a team of national agricultural researchers. 
The working groups will (i) support the formulation of the master plan, (ii) contribute appropriate 
data and information for the preparation of subsector reports, (iii) determine client research 
needs of farmers and other stakeholders through a series of consultations, and (iv) prepare 
preliminary research activity portfolios for program planning and priority setting during the 
formulation of a master plan. The consultant team recruited under the TA will closely work with 
these working groups for the formulation of the master plan. Key stakeholders will be consulted 
throughout the process, and will participate in workshops to discuss and resolve issues, and set 
the research program agenda.  
 
15.  The TA will be carried out during 9 months, from April to December 2004. At least three 
tripartite review meetings involving the Government, the TA consultant team, and ADB will be 
organized to review the progress and resolve any outstanding policy and implementation issues. 
The thematic group of external funding agencies for the agriculture sector will be regularly briefed 
on the progress of the TA. The consulting services required under the TA include (i) 8 person-
months of international consultants in the fields of agricultural research management and 
agricultural economics; and (ii) 12 person-months of domestic consultants in the fields of 
agricultural research policy, research systems, environment, and social and gender analysis. 
The international consultant for agricultural research management will be the team leader. An 
international  research  organization  or  consulting  firm  will  provide  all  the  international and 
domestic  consulting  services  required  for  the  TA.  The  selection  and  engagement  of  the 
consultants for the TA will be done by ADB in accordance with the ADB's Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic 
consultants. ADB's standard quality- and cost-based selection method will be used for the 
selection, and ADB will request simplified technical proposals from the shortlisted consulting 
firms. The consultant will purchase necessary office equipment in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines for Procurement. Equipment procured under the TA will be handed over to the 
Government at TA completion. 
 
16.  The consultant will prepare (i) an inception report, including a detailed work program for 
the TA, to be submitted within 3 weeks of the start of the TA and to be discussed at the initial 
tripartite review meeting; (ii) an interim report, which is the first draft of the master plan 
presenting preliminary findings based on the TA's interim results during the first phase, to be 
submitted within 4 months of the TA and to be discussed at stakeholder workshops and at the 
interim tripartite review meeting; (iii) a draft final report (the second draft of the master plan), at 
least 2 months before the completion of the TA and to be discussed at regional and national 
seminars, and at the final tripartite review meeting; and (iv) a final report, to be presented as the 
master plan upon completion of the TA. The reports will be translated into the Khmer language 
as appropriate. A preliminary outline of the final report is in Appendix 4. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Cambodia for formulating a Master Plan for National Agricultural Research, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Agricultural Research Management Specialist and Team Leader  (international, 5 
person-months) 
1.  The consultant will work closely with the working groups to develop renewed strategies 
and a vision for national agricultural research, and to propose structural options for improved 
organization and management for the research system. Specifically, the consultant will 
(i)  develop a detailed work program to specify tasks, responsibilities, and time 
schedules; 
(ii)  examine the lessons and experience in other countries in Asia that are applicable 
to Cambodia; 
(iii)  help  organize  and  facilitate  workshops  with  key  stakeholders  involved  in  
agricultural research that discuss future visions for national agricultural research 
and identify strategic issues; 
(iv)  develop  appropriate  methods  and  criteria  for  priority  setting  in  view  of  the 
Government's  development  objectives,  relevance  to  clients,  and  viability  of 
research programs; 
(v)  estimate the resource requirements for the priority research programs in the 
medium term in terms of funding, facilities, equipment, and human resources; 
(vi)  conduct an institutional analysis of strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and 
threats (SWOT) to identify institutional issues and recommend a sustainable and 
client-oriented national system for agricultural research; 
(vii)  formulate  structural  options  for  an  effective  research  system  capable  of 
responding to changed research needs at different levels in the country and 
ensuring sound governance; 
(viii)  examine mandate and regulatory issues in agricultural research and extension in 
line with the Government's policy for decentralization of decision-making and 
devolution of service delivery; 
(ix)  examine methods and procedures to promote effective partnerships and linkages 
in agricultural research and extension; 
(x)  examine possible access to agricultural biotechnology and its proper use; 
(xi)  assess the requirements for planning and management of research personnel 
and outline appropriate systems, including performance evaluation and incentive 
systems; 
(xii)  develop  an  action  plan  detailing  the  tasks,  responsibilities,  and  schedule  for 
program planning and priority setting; and 
(xiii)  lead the consultant team in the formulation of the master plan document. 
 
B.  Agricultural Economist (international, 3 person-months) 
2.  The consultant will work closely with the working groups to review the current situation of 
national agricultural research. Specifically, the consultant will 
(i)  review and characterize the approved policy and strategy statements of the 
Government for the agriculture sector in view of the medium-term development 
objectives described in the Second Socioeconomic Development Plan (2001–
2005); 
(ii)  assess the ongoing and planned activities of agricultural research and extension, 
in consultation with the departments of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and 
Fisheries (MAFF), research institutes, external funding agencies, and relevant

nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and from the perspectives of the 1998 
policy for national agricultural research and extension; 
(iii)  organize and facilitate stakeholder workshops that present the outcome of the 
review, and provide opportunities for discussions among key stakeholders and 
research partners, and prepare workshop reports; 
(iv)  interview the relevant government officials and other key stakeholders regarding 
agricultural research policies and strategies, and record the results; 
(v)  assess the current state of the national agricultural research system, including 
institutions, financial and human resources, facilities, equipment, and linkages; 
(vi)  assess the current system for information management and recommend an 
overall information strategy that will improve data bases on research activities, 
personnel, facilities at different levels, and monitoring and evaluation; 
(vii)  provide the thematic group of external funding agencies for the agriculture sector 
with regular briefings on the progress of  technical assistance (TA) activities; and 
(viii)  organize and facilitate priority setting workshops with key representatives from 
research,  extension,  agro-industry,  and  NGOs,  to  determine  high  priority 
research areas and programs to be implemented in the medium term. 
 
C.  Agricultural Research Policy Specialist (domestic, 5 person-months) 
3.  The consultant will be responsible for the following tasks: 
(i)  collect necessary data and information, and the documents of the Government 
and external funding agencies in the agriculture sector and with agricultural 
research policy and strategy contents; 
(ii)  prepare necessary background materials in the Khmer language, as appropriate, 
for  the  working  group  meetings  and  the  stakeholder  workshops,  including 
information  on  the  relevant  policies,  strategies,  institutional  mandates  and 
linkages; 
(iii)  organize and facilitate stakeholder workshops that present the TA findings on 
agricultural  research  policies  and  strategies,  and  provide  opportunities  for 
discussions among key stakeholders and partners to reflect their views in the TA; 
(iv)  summarize the results of the policy and strategy analysis, including adjustments 
based on workshop inputs, suitable for inclusion in the master plan document; 
(v)  establish an inventory of physical and human resources for national agricultural 
research and extension by collecting data on the existing institutions, financial 
and  human  resources,  facilities,  equipment,  and  linkages  for  a  SWOT 
institutional analysis; 
(vi)  assist the subsector working groups in identifying priority research areas and 
programs in view of the renewed strategy and vision for agricultural research; 
(vii)  assist  the  subsector  working  group  members  in  contributing  to  the  relevant 
sections of the master plan documents; 
(viii)  provide the thematic group of external funding agencies for the agriculture sector 
and the agricultural research steering committee with regular briefings on the 
progress of TA activities; and 
(ix)  ensure that the translation of the TA outputs into the Khmer language is properly 
completed.

4.  The consultant will have the following tasks: 
(i)  compile  data  and  information  to  carry  out  a  SWOT  institutional  analysis  to 
formulate viable structural options for a sustainable and client-oriented system of 
national agricultural research; 
(ii)  collect information on the existing institutions, financial and human resources,

areas and programs to mitigate possible adverse environmental impacts.
